title: Split Complementary
description: A safer version of complementary â€” one base plus two neighbors of its opposite.

hook.text: Complementary colors can be intense. What if you could get 90% of the contrast with 50% less visual vibration? Split complementary gives you exactly that.

buildup.text: Choose a base color. Find its complement. Instead of using the complement, use the two colors adjacent to it. Example: blue as base â†’ instead of orange, use red-orange and yellow-orange.

discovery.text: This creates a Y-shaped selection on the wheel. You get warm-cool contrast without the head-on clash. It's versatile, visually interesting, and much harder to mess up than a straight complementary scheme.

twist.text: It's a favorite of illustrators and designers because it's almost foolproof. The asymmetry of the split creates visual interest that pure complementary's symmetry lacks.

climax.text: Try it: pick any color. Skip its complement. Use the two colors flanking that complement. Paint a simple still life with this scheme. You'll love the result.

punchline.text: All the contrast of complements, none of the visual headache. Split complementary is the smart choice.

quiz.question: How is a split complementary scheme constructed?
options: One base color plus the two colors adjacent to its complement
